question: Question_03
statement:
A city's supply of an herb comes from many small home businesses. The
supply q of the herb is a function of the street price p. The Elasticity
of Supply is by definition equal to

\begin{align*}-\frac{p}{q}\frac{\textrm{d}q}{\textrm{d}p}.\end{align*}

Suppose that a city's weekly supply q of the herb, in millions of grams,
is related to the street price, p, in dollars per gram, by the equation

\begin{align*}\displaystyle{}p^3+p=2q^3+q^2+10.\end{align*}

Calculate the elasticity of supply when p=3. Please simplify. Note that
when p=3, we have q=2.
sols:
In order to find $dq/dp,$ we differentiate both sides of the supply
equation with respect to $p$.

\begin{align*}3p^2+1=(6q^2+2q)\frac{dq}{dp}\end{align*} Solving for $dq/dp,$

\begin{align*}\frac{dq}{dp} =\frac{3p^2+1}{6q^2+2q}\end{align*} Hence, the elasticity of
supply is

\begin{align*}-\frac{p}{q}\frac{dq}{dp} =-\frac{p}{q}\frac{3p^2+1}{6q^2+2q}.\end{align*}
Evaluating this when $p=3$ and $q=2$, we obtain

\begin{align*}-\frac{3}{2}\frac{3(3)^2+1}{6(2)^2+2(2)}=-\frac{3}{2}\frac{28}{28}=-\frac{3}{2}.\end{align*}
hints:
Note that the definition of elasticity depends varies from person to
person and text to text; depending on where you look, you may or may not
find a minus sign in front of $\frac{p}{q} \frac{dq}{dp}.$ For this
problem, we are given a definition, so we'll use this in the solution.
On your exam, you might not be given the definition of elasticity. In
this case, please use the definition that you were given in class. (In
2012, we did not include a minus sign in front.)
